questions.text: A 45-year woman presents to the OPD for evaluation of irregular menstrual bleeding. The patient had inter-menstrual bleeding for the past 8 months and this has now become progressively prolonged such that she has been bleeding on almost all days of the month. The patient previously used an LNG-IUS for contraception for 10 years but had it removed a year earlier after her husband underwent a vasectomy. She takes no medication and is a non-smoker. Her BMI is 38. Abdominal exam is normal and bimanual exam is also normal. There are no cervical or vaginal lesions. A hysteroscopic biopsy is done which shows simple endometrial hyperplasia. Which is the most likely cause of this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Peripheral aromatization of androgens to estrogen

options.label: D
options.text: Invasion of endometrial tissue into the myometrium

questions.correct_answer: C. Peripheral aromatization of androgens to estrogen
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient most likely has endometrial hyperplasia due to hyperestrogenism. A possible reason for the hyperestrogenism is the high BMI where there is peripheral aromatization of androgens to estrogen
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: Continuous exposure to progesterone: continupis exposure to progesterone would lead to endometrial atrophy. This woman had an LNG IUD for 10 years. This would have led to endometrial atrophy but she has stopped using it for a year and this would have led to endometrial hyperplasia. If he had continued to be on the LNG IUD, she would not have developed this condition Option B: Ectopic implantation of endometrial glands: This is endometriosis; and will not present with AUB. Endometriosis would present with pain and dysmenorrhoea. A Option D: Invasion of endometrial tissue into the myometrium: This is adenomyosis; this presents as menorrhagia and dysmenorrhoea. Also in adenomyosis, there would be a regularly enlarged uterus.

questions.text: A 32-year P3 comes to OPD with AUB. Menarche was at age 13 years, and she has had regular cycles till 1 year ago. She then began to have delayed periods every 45-60 days with heavy bleeding, clots but no cramping. She has not had her period in 4 months. She has no hot flushes, acne, or abnormal hair growth. She takes levo-thyroxine for hypothyroidism and has had a tubal ligation done. Height is 160 cm, weight is 120kg. P/S is normal. Bimanual exam is limited by body habitus. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Lab tests are as follows: TSH- 2.9, Prolactin: 16, LH: 15 What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This patient is having anovulatory cycles. This is because She is obese and this causes insulin resistance and hyperglycemia with decreased production of SHBG causing elevated androgen levels. This androgen gets aromatized to estrone which leads to persistent elevated estrogen levels. This results in anovulation due to the imbalance in LH and FSH (High LH: FSH ratio in PCOS which is the commonest cause of anovulatory cycles)

questions.text: A 52y woman who has been menopausal for more than a year presents to the OPD with complains of bleeding since 3 days. She thinks it may be a part of menopause but is a little concerned as she used to have heavy bleeding during her periods several years earlier. She is on anti-hypertensives. On examination, her vitals are stable. Abdominal exam is unremarkable. A speculum exam shows a normal cervix with blood visible at the os. The uterus is normal in size. A transvaginal scan shows an endometrial thickness of 8mm with b/l normal ovaries. What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • This is a woman who is having post-menopausal bleeding (PMB) The most common causes of PMB is endometrial atrophy but also it is important to rule out malignancies in this age group As the cervix appears normal and the TVS shows an increased endometrial thickness (it should be < 5mm in the post-menopausal age group), the next best step would be to take an endometrial biopsy. This can be done by Office biopsy (Endometrial aspiration) Dilatation and curettage Hysteroscopic guided biopsy (gold standard)

This can be done by Office biopsy (Endometrial aspiration) Dilatation and curettage Hysteroscopic guided biopsy (gold standard)

However in post menopausal bleeding, the main aim is to rule out a malignancy Option B: Hysterectomy: This won't be the initial step. The initial step is to diagnose the cause of post menopsuasal bleeding Option C: Trans-cervical resection of the endometrium: This is a type of endometrial ablation and is recommended in heavy menstrual bleeding. It is however c/i in premalignant and malignant lesions and those need to be ruled out by an endometrial biopsy

questions.text: A 15y girl is brought to the emergency room by her mother. She has been bleeding heavily since 20 days. There is no dysmenorrhea. She attained menarche about 2 years ago and since then she has been having periods every 45-60 days. On examination, she appears pale. Her vitals are stable. Her BMI is 18. Abdomen is soft. An ultrasound reveals a normal uterus with an endometrial thickness of 4mm. Both the ovaries are normal on the scan. Her Hb is 9g%. TSH is 2.5 and a coagulation profile is normal. The next best management is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. High dose progesterone

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This is a case of puberty menorrhagia It is seen in puberty due to an immature HPO axis and anovulation After initial management, if bleeding doesn’t stop and it is primarily due to anovulation, high dose progesterone help to stop the bleeding (Medroxy-progesterone acetate or nor-ethisterone acetate)

  • • Option A: Dilatation and curettage: This is not an initial step in management of puberty menorrhagia. It is considered only when medical management fails to control the bleeding. Option C: Blood transfusion: This is indicated in severe anemia. This patients Hb is 9g%. Option D: Inj GnRH agonist: This is indicated for precocious puberty and not puberty menorhagia
